channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: White House downplays new Epstein emails that mention Trump
item.description: The House Oversight Committee has released a new tranche of documents, including several emails from the estate of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein that refer to President Trump.
item.content:encoded:
The House Oversight Committee has released a new tranche of documents, including several emails from the estate of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein that refer to President Trump.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Stephen Fowler

item.title: House set to vote on bill to end the longest shutdown as Democrats remain divided
item.description: The House may vote as early as Wednesday afternoon on a measure that will end the longest government shutdown in U.S. history, but Democrats remain deeply divided about whether to support it.
item.content:encoded: The House may vote as early as Wednesday afternoon on a measure that will end the longest government shutdown in U.S. history, but Democrats remain deeply divided about whether to support it.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Grisales

item.title: Rep. Mike Lawler, R-N.Y., talks about upcoming House vote to end the shutdown
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Republican Congressman Mike Lawler of New York about the imminent House vote on a deal to end the longest shutdown in U.S. history.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Republican Congressman Mike Lawler of New York about the imminent House vote on a deal to end the longest shutdown in U.S. history.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Immigration is a key issue at this week's U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops
item.description: The U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops met in Baltimore this week to elect a new leader and renew their commitment to advocate on behalf of migrants in the U.S.
item.content:encoded: The U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops met in Baltimore this week to elect a new leader and renew their commitment to advocate on behalf of migrants in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Aleja Hertzler-McCain

item.title: Rep. Katherine Clark, D-Mass., talks about upcoming vote to reopen the government
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with House Democratic Whip Katherine Clark of Massachusetts about the pending vote on a measure to end the government shutdown.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with House Democratic Whip Katherine Clark of Massachusetts about the pending vote on a measure to end the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: The first 'Netflix House' is open — with virtual reality, mini-golf and lots of selfies
item.description: The company's first permanent in-person space is a former Lord & Taylor department store in the King of Prussia Mall outside Philadelphia. Locations are on the way in Dallas and Las Vegas.
item.content:encoded:
The company's first permanent in-person space is a former Lord & Taylor department store in the King of Prussia Mall outside Philadelphia. Locations are on the way in Dallas and Las Vegas.

(Image credit: Kat Kendon)
item.dc:creator: Neda Ulaby

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The House prepares for a vote to reopen the government, airlines warn delays could persist even after the shutdown ends, U.S. aircraft carrier to join military buildup near Venezuela.
item.content:encoded: The House prepares for a vote to reopen the government, airlines warn delays could persist even after the shutdown ends, U.S. aircraft carrier to join military buildup near Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez

item.title: This 26-year-old political strategist has a new vision for the Democratic Party
item.description: Morris Katz is a 26-year-old political strategist who wants to take the Democratic party in a new direction. Leila Fadel talks to him about the candidates he's backing and his vision for the future.
item.content:encoded: Morris Katz is a 26-year-old political strategist who wants to take the Democratic party in a new direction. Leila Fadel talks to him about the candidates he's backing and his vision for the future.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: Iran rebuilding after U.S. strikes on nuclear facilities, report says
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep talks to Joseph Rodgers, the author of a report on Iran's development of nuclear weapons. Rodgers says satellite images indicate activity has resumed after the U.S. strikes on nuclear facilities in Iran.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep talks to Joseph Rodgers, the author of a report on Iran's development of nuclear weapons. Rodgers says satellite images indicate activity has resumed after the U.S. strikes on nuclear facilities in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: Iraq votes for new parliament amid U.S. pressure to counter Iran's influence
item.description: Iraqis are awaiting the preliminary results of Tuesday's election for a new parliament, as Washington watches closely and pressures Iraq's government to curb neighboring Iran's influence.
item.content:encoded: Iraqis are awaiting the preliminary results of Tuesday's election for a new parliament, as Washington watches closely and pressures Iraq's government to curb neighboring Iran's influence.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
